titleStmt.title: The victorious proceedings of the Protestant armie in Ireland vnder the command of the Right Honourable Maj. Gen. Iones, in his late expedition against the Irish rebels. Wherein is set forth, severall great overthrowes, given to the said rebles, since the 9. of October last, 1647. As also the manner of the taking of 10. strong castles belonging to the enemy, with the losse of few men, together with all their armes, and ammunition. Being a full and perfect relation of the severall victories obtained from the 9. of October till the 20. of November. 1647.
titleStmt.author: R. B.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 10 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 5 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

titleStmt.title: The victorious proceedings of the Protestant armie in Ireland vnder the command of the Right Honourable Maj. Gen. Iones, in his late expedition against the Irish rebels. Wherein is set forth, severall great overthrowes, given to the said rebles, since the 9. of October last, 1647. As also the manner of the taking of 10. strong castles belonging to the enemy, with the losse of few men, together with all their armes, and ammunition. projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

keywords.term: Great Britain -- History -- Civil War, 1642-1649 -- Campaigns -- Ireland -- Early works to 1800.

div.p: THE VICTORIOUS PROCEEDINGS OF THE PROTESTANT ARMIE IN IRELAND.
Vnder the Command of the Right Honourable Maj. Gen. Iones, in his late expedition again≈øt the Iri≈øh Rebels.

WHEREIN IS SET FORTH, Severall great Overthrowes, given to the ≈øaid Rebels, ≈øince the 9. of October la≈øt, 1647. As al≈øo the manner of the taking of 10. ≈øtrong Ca≈øtles belonging to the enemy, with the lo≈ø≈øe of few men, together with all their Armes, and Ammunition.
Being a full and perfect Relation of the ≈øeverall Victories obtained from the 9. of October till the 20. of November, 1647.

p.hi: LONDON Printed by B. A. for further ≈øatisfaction.

div.head: The further ≈øucce≈ø≈øefull Proceedings of the Prote≈øtant Army in Ireland, commanded by Colonell Michael Jones.
div.p: ACcording to my promi≈øe, I here tender unto you the further relation of the proceedings of our army; al≈øo the taking of Athboy, and after the Gen ‚Ä¢ rall had di≈øpo≈øed of the pri≈øoners, and placed a Gari≈øon there, he marched to Kells five miles Northwards from Athboy, and there quartered; and that night Sir Tho. Atme≈øtrong with a party of 500. hor≈øe was ≈øent into the County of Cavan, to harra≈øe and prey that Country.

Sunday the x. of October, we marched from Hells northward, ≈øeverall Ca≈øtles in the Country quitting their Garri≈øons, and about 11. of the clock we came before a very ≈øtrong Fort, called Ardtonian, alias Cumce ‚Ä¢
Fort, the Generall cau≈øed the place to be ≈øummoned; whereupon an Officer came forth, & after parley, de≈øired quarter, which being granted, there marched forth Lieut. Comice, an En≈øigne, 38. Souldiers, a Piper, & a great ≈øort of their na≈øty Country women & children the Gen. left captain Richard Perkins of Col. Kinna≈øtons Regiment, & 70 men in Garri≈øon there. This day Sir Jo. Gifford with a party of hor≈øe brought in a prey of Cowes & Sheepe, a great reliefe to the Army. Then the army marched 3 miles from thence to a place called Nebber (a Ca≈øtle & Fort of Earth, ≈øurrounded
with water of great ≈øtrength) it ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ng ≈ø ‚Ä¢ mmoned, the Commander within de≈øired that one from Us might be ≈øent in, & he would ≈øend one to our Campe, and by eight of the clock next morning, would re≈øolve the Generall what he would doe, Major Miles Somne ‚Ä¢
Ingeneer Generall to the Army, was ≈øent by the Generall in, where he remained that night, and one Pluncket was ≈øent forth, who likewi≈øe remained n the Campe that night.

Munday October the 11. Major Semur came forth and certified the place to be of great ≈øtrength, about 11 of the clock after long debate (the con≈øequence of the place requiring of it) they had quarter to march with Arms, Bag and Baggage, with a fourth part of their corne: There marched thence, a Lieutenant and an En≈øigne, and about 70. men, with a great number of their old retirue of women and children, Lieutenant Colonell Napper of Colonell King≈øtons Regiment is now in Garri≈øon there.

Tue≈øday the 12. of October, after the Gen. had ≈øetled his bu≈øine≈ø≈øe about the Nebber, he marched to Ballagh ‚Ä¢ o (a very ill pa≈ø≈øage for our Ordnance and Carriages) In our march thither Sir Thomas Arm≈øtrong with the party of hor≈øe under his command, came to the Army with a very good prey of cattell, at that time a great relief to the Army, being in great want of Victuals, when we came to Ballagh ‚Ä¢ o (a very ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle with great Works) upon a pa≈ø≈øe lying on the laggan water; which ≈øevers the Countries of Meath, Lowth, and Mounaghan, each from other, and commands all that part of the Country. It was immediatly ≈øummoned, they within refu≈øing to yeeld, the Gen. cau≈øed ≈øtrong guards both of hor≈øe and foot to watch the place all night.

Wedne≈øday the 13 of Octob. our Ordinance by rea≈øon of the badne≈ø≈øe of the waies came not to us till noon, when a≈ø≈øoon as they in the Ca≈øtle perceived them come, they de≈øired to parley, which being hearkened unto, (for the Works and Ca≈øtle could not be gained by all likelihood without great lo≈ø≈øe) it was agreed they ≈øhould march away with their Arms, Bag and Baggage (not march worth) there marched away Col: Fleming Commander of the Ca≈øtle, an En≈øign and 47 Souldie ‚Ä¢ s, Lieutenant Colonel Blagvale of Col: Moores Reg. was left in garri≈øon there.

Thur≈øday the 14 of Octob. we marched clo≈øe under the Ca≈øtle of Ballaghoo over the pa≈ø≈øe (a very dangerous Foord) into the County of Manughan, and leaving Carrigment Ro≈øse on our right hand whither the Britti≈øh forces marched, we marched into the County of Cavan, and came to a place called Cabbvagh belonging to one Thomas Fleming (now of the Rebels ≈øupreme Councell,) a place commanding all that part of the Country, which being ≈øummoned, took quarter and delivered up the Ca≈øtle, there marched thence 12 Musketeers to another Garri≈øon of the enemies called the Nogh, this place was left to Col: Monk to ≈ølight or ≈øettle a Garri≈øon there, as he ≈øhould think fit, it being in the Province of Ul≈øter.

Friday the 15 of Octob. the Army remained at Cabbvagh, and the Gen. with ≈øome hor≈øe marched to another Garri≈øon of theirs called the Nogh 2 miles from Cabbvagh, a place of very great ≈øtrength, commanded by a ≈øon of Tho. Flemings, there was a great ≈øtore of corne about this place, the Ca≈øtle being ≈øummoned took quarter, and they marched away with Bag and Baggage. A Troop of Col: Pon≈øonbyes Regiment of hor≈øe is now in Garri≈øon at the Nogh.

Col. Monk with the Ul≈øter Forces ≈øate down before
„Äà‚óä„Äâ I≈ølands in a low clo≈øe under Carrick Mac ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ff, after ≈øome ≈øhot made, tho≈øe in the I≈øland cryed out for quarter, and had it granted: there was great ≈øtore of Meale and Corn, & other Country provi≈øions found in tho≈øe I≈ølands, the Country all about was burnt.

Satterday the 12. of Octob. the Gen. & Col. Monk met at Cabbragh afore≈øaid in the county of Cavad, and after ≈øome con≈øultation, our Forces and the Ul≈øter Forces parted, they homewards, and we marched neere to a place called Roffine in the County of Meath, where wee quartered that night, and received intelligence of out Convoy formerly ≈øent to Dublin, to be neer, and marching to us.

Sunday the 17. of Octob. about ten of the clock, we met with our Convoy, which brought provi≈øion of Bisket & cheefe to the army, then ≈øtanding in a great need thereof: from this place the Gen. ≈øent col. Coot, to garri≈øon at a place called Roffine, about which is great ≈øtore of corne. Sir Patrick Weames, & capt. Richard Burrowes to Mogalty, part of col. Pon≈øo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ies hor≈øe to Nobber & Ardloman. the Gen. di≈ømi≈øt col. Moor & the Dundalke Forces home to their quarters, and he marched to Durmoe, a ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle of the Rebels upon the River of Reyn (the la≈øt Garri≈øon of the Enemies in the Engli≈øh quarters) it being ≈øummoned, tooke quarter to march away with their ≈øwords and cloakes only, Lieut. Delamare and 24. men. In this ca≈øtle is Capt. Roe of Col. Hungerfords Regiment left in gari≈øon. The army marched over the Royne (a very untoward cro≈ø≈øe way for our Ordinance) and that night wee quartered at n place called Dullard≈øtone.

Munday the 18. of Octob. we marched from Dullard≈øtone, and this day the General di≈ømi≈øt the Drogheda forces
home to their quarters. This thy we quartered at a place called Killeglan within ten miles of Dublin.

Tue≈øday the 19. of Octob. we marched from Killeglan towards Dublin, in the way the Lord Moore tooke his leave of the Generall, and went to his quarters to Melli ‚Ä¢
fort, and the night we marched to the city of Dublin, to the great rejoycing of the well-affected Citizens, who in our ab≈øence lo≈øt neer upon 600. Cowes taken from them by the Rebels.

Thus have I endeavoured to give you a full and perfect accompt of the proceedings of our Army in their la ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ march abroad, and if it plea≈øed God ≈øo to put in the hart of the Parliament there as to looke upon us with ≈øome ≈øupply of money, I make no doubt, with Gods a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, the Rebels hearts would quickly be quite broke: if money be not ≈øent, things will go very cro≈ø≈øe, and we in great danger among our own party here. God Almighty ≈øtirre ‚Ä¢ y their hearts to look upon us here, I am

div.head: Po≈øt-≈øcript.
div.p: AFter the returne of our Army to the City of Dublin, the Generall ≈øent out a party of hor≈øe into the County of Wickl ‚Ä¢ e, who brought with them a good prey of Cattle to Dublin, which was a great reliefe to the Army, the 23 of October, the Generall commandes to be kept as a day of Thank≈øgiving for the great deliverance from the Iri≈øh Rebellion, and for the good ≈øucce≈ø≈øes God had been plea≈øed to give him in this his Expedition.
